Are you covering the post-election audits? Be sure to get clear on what audits do & don’t say about the voting process.

Watch this recording of our event with @aztammyp & @benadida to learn how to break down the complex audit process for your audience: https://t.co/o6IdDKdEBS

#3: Personal commentary from reporters about a crisis is best received when it focuses on community unity and healing. 

"Journalists [should] be aware of public sentiment in their community surrounding the event before tweeting an opinion."
text.2:
#2: Dedicate reporting staff to answering questions on social media to alleviate concerns about the disaster.

"Conversations between journalists and the public...helps to establish long-term trust and loyalty between a local news organization and its community."
text.3:
#1: Focus on facts, keep them simple and repeat them often.

"During the initial days of a crisis, it is hard for the public to absorb all of the information they are given...fear and uncertainty can even lead to 'cognitive freezing.'”
text.4:
A new study examining how audiences respond to crisis coverage on Twitter found that they most often engage with information on how to stay safe.

@EngagingNews' @marleyduchovnay breaks the findings down into 3 priorities for journalists.  https://t.co/jd8diJovnb
